questions.question_text: An engineer has successfully established a Phase 1 and Phase 2 tunnel between two sites. Site A has internal subnet 192.168.0.0/24 and Site B has internal subnet 10.0.0.0/24. The engineer notices that no packets are decrypted at Site B. Pings to 192.168.0.1 from internal Site B devices make it to the Site B router, and the Site A router has incrementing encrypt and decrypt counters. What must be done to ensure bidirectional communication between both sites?

discussion.content:
If the Phase 1 and Phase 2 tunnels have been successfully established between Site A and Site B, and pings from internal devices at Site B reach the Site B router but are not decrypted, the issue might be related to the firewall in front of the Site B router. In this case, to ensure bidirectional communication between the two sites, you need to allow the encapsulating security payload (ESP) protocol through the firewall.

Therefore, the correct action would be to "Allow protocol ESP on the firewall in front of the Site B router."

ESP (Encapsulating Security Payload) is a protocol used in IPsec to provide encryption, integrity, and authentication of packets. If ESP traffic is blocked by the firewall, it can prevent the successful decryption of packets arriving at Site B.

AH (Authentication Header) is another IPsec protocol, but it does not provide encryption and is less commonly used. In a typical IPsec configuration, ESP is used for encryption and authentication, so allowing ESP is usually the correct step to ensure the bidirectional communication is successful.
C is correct answer
Why the answer is C? It says "successfully established a Phase 1 and Phase 2 tunnel between two sites" Doesn't that mean ESP or AH already allowed?

comments.content:
A is incorrect: site A is receiving packets as its decrypt counter is increasing
B is incorrect: both phase 1 and phase 2 tunnels are successful meaning DH matches
C is correct: IKE uses UDP/500 to communicate both phase 1 and phase 2. After phase 2 is completed, IPsec uses those keys for either ESP or AH. Site A is sending so it has a route. That means site B must be blocking protocol 50 or 51.
D is incorrect: PFS is optional. If this would not match, the phase 2 tunnel would not appear.
neglect my comment. Site B has routing in place >> packets reach site A, thus the decrypt counter increases there.

discussion.content: Not sure. Decrypt packets counter not increasing in one side might be routing issue.

choices.B: Configure the correct DH group on both devices.
choices.D: Enable PFS on the headend device.
choices.A: Modify the routing at Site B so that traffic is sent to Site A.
choices.C: Allow protocol ESP or AH on the firewall in front of the Site B router.

choices.D: Modify the crypto ACL on the router to permit network 172.16.20.0/24 to network 192.168.0.0/24.
choices.B: Modify the crypto ACL on the ASA to permit network 192.168.0.0/24 to network 172.16.20.0/24.
choices.C: Modify the crypto ACL on the ASA to permit network 172.16.20.0/24 to network 192.168.0.0/24.
choices.A: Modify the crypto ACL on the router to permit network 192.168.0.0/24 to network 172.16.20.0/24.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
the show crypto ukev2 sa output from the ASA, the local selector is 192.168.0.0/24 the remote selector is 172.16.2.0/24 ( which is wrong , should be .20.0/24) . so , the ACL in the ASA should be to permit 192.168.0.0/24 to 172.16.20.0/24
I saw this on the test and the network was 172.16.2.0/24 everywhere (question and answers) so nothing wrong on the ASA AC.

Selected Answer: B
B according to the output

Selected Answer: B

Selected Answer: B
I think the correct answer is B, for answer A we get different error message "WebVPN session terminated: Client type not supported".

There are 2 types of SSL VPN license:

1) AnyConnect Essential license - only supports AnyConnect client connections

2) AnyConnect Premium license (user base license) - supports all flavours of SSL VPN, including: clientless SSL VPN, AnyConnect client VPN, and all the advanced features of SSL VPN.

The correct answer seems to "A". To resolve the error message "clientless (browser) SSLVPN access is not allowed" on a Cisco ASA, the administrator should take the following step:

Enable the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy.
This error suggests that the clientless SSLVPN access is not allowed, and enabling the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy is the appropriate action to permit users to connect using the clientless SSLVPN feature.

Here's a brief explanation of the options:

Enable the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy: This step allows the ASA to use clientless SSLVPN for users associated with that specific group policy.

Validate that the correct license is in use on the ASA for WebVPN: While licensing is crucial for certain features, the specific error message provided indicates a configuration issue related to clientless SSLVPN access. Validating the license is a good practice, but the immediate resolution for this particular error is typically related to the configuration.

Ensure that the group policy associated with the user allows clientless SSLVPN access, and verify the relevant settings to enable clientless SSLVPN on the Cisco ASA.

correct answer is B:
The message "Clientless (browser) SSL VPN access is not allowed." appears in the browser after an unsuccessful login attempt. The AnyConnect Premium license is not installed on the ASA or it is not in use as shown by "Premium AnyConnect license is not enabled on the ASA."
Solution:
Enable the Premium AnyConnect license with these commands:
ASA(config)# webvpn
ASA(config-webvpn)# no anyconnect-essentials

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. https://community.cisco.com/t5/vpn/clientless-vpn-clientless-browser-ssl-vpn-access-is-not-allowed/td-p/1569690

questions.question_text: A user is trying to log in to a Cisco ASA using the clientless SSLVPN feature and receives the error message "clientless (browser) SSLVPN access is not allowed". Which step should the Cisco ASA administrator take to resolve this issue?

choices.D: Verify that a user account exists in the local AAA database for the user.
choices.C: Increase the number of simultaneous logins allowed on the group policy.
choices.B: Validate that the correct license is in use on the ASA for WebVPN.
choices.A: Enable the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy.

questions.question_text: Which feature allows a DMVPN Phase 3 spoke to switch to an alternate hub when the primary hub is unreachable?

discussion.content: The feature that allows a DMVPN Phase 3 spoke to switch to an alternate hub when the primary hub is unreachable is "backup NHS" (Next Hop Server). In DMVPN Phase 3, the spoke routers register with a Next Hop Server (NHS) to obtain the routing information for other spokes in the network. The backup NHS feature allows a spoke to have multiple NHSs configured, where the primary NHS is the preferred hub, and the backup NHSs act as alternatives. If the primary hub becomes unreachable, the spoke router will automatically switch to using one of the configured backup NHSs as the new hub. This ensures that the spoke can maintain connectivity and continue routing traffic even if the primary hub goes offline. On the other hand, NHRP (Next Hop Resolution Protocol) shortcuts are used in DMVPN to dynamically establish direct spoke-to-spoke tunnels, bypassing the hub router. NHRP shortcuts improve efficiency and reduce latency by allowing spokes to communicate directly with each other. However, it is the backup NHS feature that specifically addresses the issue of switching to an alternate hub in case of primary hub unavailability.
So many wrong answers. Can't depend on this website at all

Selected Answer: B
B Is correct

Selected Answer: B
The DMVPN-Tunnel Health Monitoring and Recovery (Backup NHS) feature allows you to control the number of connections to the Dynamic Multipoint Virtual Private Network (DMVPN) hub and allows you to switch to alternate hubs in case of a connection failure to the primary hubs.
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_conn_dmvpn/configuration/15-2mt/sec-conn-dmvpn-backup-nhs.html#:~:text=The%20DMVPN%2DTunnel%20Health%20Monitoring%20and%20Recovery%20(Backup%20NHS),failure%20to%20the%20primary%20hubs.

questions.question_text: An engineer is using DMVPN to provide secure connectivity between a data center and remote sites. Which two routing protocols should be used between the routers? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
https://orhanergun.net/dmvpn#:~:text=Two%20standard%20routing%20protocols%20used%20in%20DMVPNs%20are%20OSPF%20and%20EIGRP.%20Both%20provide%20fast%20convergence%20and%20support%20for%20IPv4%20and%20IPv6%20addresses%2C%20making%20them%20versatile%20options%20for%20networking%20environments.

what question is this ? in theory DMVPN can use BGP , RIPv2 , OSPF , EIGRP...
EIGRP is cisco's product so let's say we should choose it and BGP is also a good choice

Not sure about OSPF or BGP... I will choose BGP because OSPF is too complex for this scenario
